text: If you want to accomplish something truly extraordinary, if you want to be in the 99th percentile in terms of outcomes, it's going to be really difficult. It's going to be really uncomfortable. And you got to sort of remind people of that, that if they ever find themselves in the comfort zone at work, they are definitely making a mistake.
speaker: Matt MacInnis
context: Lenny asks Matt about his philosophy that extraordinary results require extraordinary efforts. Matt explains that achieving exceptional outcomes - being in the 99th percentile - requires accepting that the work will be difficult and uncomfortable. He emphasizes that if someone finds themselves comfortable at work, they're likely not pushing hard enough to achieve extraordinary results.
text_ko: 정말 특별한 성과를 내고 싶고, 결과 면에서 상위 1퍼센타일(99th percentile)에 들고 싶다면 그건 정말 힘들고 많이 불편할 거예요. 사람들에게도 그 점을 계속 상기시켜 줘야 해요. 직장에서 안전지대(comfort zone)에 머무르고 있다면 분명 실수를 하고 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你想做出真正了不起的成绩，想要进入那1%的顶尖行列，那肯定会特别难，特别不舒服。你得经常提醒大家，如果在工作中感觉太舒适了，那绝对是走错路了。
text_es: Si quieres lograr algo realmente extraordinario, si quieres estar en el percentil 99 en cuanto a resultados, va a ser súper difícil. Te va a hacer sentir muy incómodo. Y tienes que recordarle a la gente que si alguna vez se encuentran en su zona de confort en el trabajo, definitivamente están cometiendo un error.

text: The extraordinary effort thing is a reminder that it's supposed to be really fricking exhausting. It's supposed to be. So on Friday night, when you get hit with an escalation on Friday night, when you get sort of hit with a bunch of new bugs from someone in the engineering team that you've got a triage, those are the moments where great players and great teams are separated from good players and good teams.
speaker: Matt MacInnis
context: Matt continues explaining his extraordinary efforts philosophy by giving concrete examples. He describes how the work should feel exhausting and points to specific scenarios - like getting escalations on Friday nights or having to triage bugs - as the defining moments that separate great teams from merely good ones. These challenging moments are when superior performance is demonstrated.
text_ko: '엄청난 노력'이라는 얘기는 그 일이 정말 고되고 지치게 마련이라는 걸 상기시켜줘요. 그래야 해요. 그래서 금요일 밤에 에스컬레이션(escalation)이 들어오거나 엔지니어링팀(engineering team)에서 새 버그(bug)들이 몰려와서 트리아지(triage)를 해야 할 때가 바로 훌륭한 사람과 팀이 그저 괜찮은 사람과 팀과 갈리는 순간이에요.
text_zh: 超常努力这件事提醒我们，工作本来就应该累得要死，就是应该这样。所以周五晚上，当你突然遇到紧急情况需要处理，或者工程团队那边突然冒出一堆新的bug需要你去分类处理，这些时候就是区分顶尖选手和普通选手、顶尖团队和普通团队的关键时刻。
text_es: La cosa del esfuerzo extraordinario es un recordatorio de que se supone que tiene que ser súper agotador. Así es como debe ser. Entonces el viernes por la noche, cuando te cae una escalación, cuando te llueven un montón de bugs nuevos del equipo de ingeniería que tienes que priorizar, esos son los momentos donde se separan los jugadores y equipos extraordinarios de los que son solo buenos.

text: It is really important to me that we feel that we've deliberately understaffed every project at the company. If you overstaff, you get politics, you get people working on things that are further down the priority list than necessary. That is poison. It's wasteful. It slows you down. It creates cruft.
speaker: Matt MacInnis
context: Matt explains his management philosophy about staffing projects. He advocates for deliberately understaffing rather than overstaffing because overstaffing leads to negative consequences like office politics and people working on lower-priority tasks. He uses the term 'cruft' to describe the unnecessary complexity and waste that comes from having too many people on a project.
text_ko: 회사의 모든 프로젝트에서 일부러 인력을 줄였다는 느낌이 정말 중요해요. 인력이 과다하면 정치적 문제도 생기고, 우선순위가 낮은 일에 사람들이 시간을 쓰게 되거든요. 그건 독이 되고, 낭비가 되고, 속도를 늦추고, 불필요한 것들이 쌓이게 해요.
text_zh: 对我来说特别重要的一点是，我们公司每个项目都要故意少配人手。如果人员冗余的话，就会产生办公室政治，大家就会去搞一些不那么重要的事情。这简直是毒药，既浪费资源，又拖慢进度，还会产生各种没用的东西。
text_es: Es súper importante para mí que sintamos que hemos dejado deliberadamente pocos recursos humanos en cada proyecto de la empresa. Si pones demasiada gente, empiezas a tener política interna, gente trabajando en cosas que están muy abajo en la lista de prioridades cuando no es necesario. Eso es veneno. Es un desperdicio. Te frena. Crea pura basura (cruft).

text: Fundamentally, the most selfish thing you can do is withhold feedback from someone. When you think a thought that would help someone improve and you avoid giving it to them because it would make you uncomfortable. Well, you're optimizing for your own comfort, and it's fundamentally selfish.
speaker: Matt MacInnis
context: Lenny mentions that Matt is a big fan of escalating issues, and Matt explains his philosophy on feedback. He argues that withholding helpful feedback from someone because it makes you uncomfortable is the most selfish behavior possible. This is because you're prioritizing your own comfort over helping someone else improve and grow professionally.
text_ko: 근본적으로, 누군가에게 피드백(feedback)을 주지 않는 게 가장 이기적인 행동이에요. 누군가가 발전하는 데 도움이 될 말이 떠올랐는데 내가 불편할까 봐 그걸 말하지 않는다면 자기 편안함만을 우선하는 거고, 결국 정말 이기적인 행동이에요.
text_zh: 说白了，最自私的事情就是不给别人反馈。你明明想到了能帮人家改进的点子，但因为怕自己不舒服就不说出来。这其实就是为了让自己舒服，本质上就是自私。
text_es: En el fondo, lo más egoísta que puedes hacer es no darle feedback a alguien. Cuando tienes una idea que podría ayudar a esa persona a mejorar y no se la das porque te va a resultar incómodo... bueno, estás priorizando tu propia comodidad, y eso es puro egoísmo.

text: The purest form of ambition and most intense source of energy in the business is the founder CEO. Every next concentric circle of management beyond the founder CEO has the potential to be an order of magnitude drop off in intensity. That is fucking dangerous.
speaker: Matt MacInnis
context: Matt discusses organizational dynamics and how intensity can diminish as you move away from the founder. He explains that founder CEOs typically have the highest level of ambition and energy, but each layer of management below them risks dramatically reducing that intensity - potentially by an order of magnitude. He sees this dilution of intensity as a serious threat to organizational performance.
text_ko: 비즈니스에서는 야망의 가장 순수한 형태이자 에너지의 가장 강렬한 원천이 창업자 겸 CEO(founder CEO)예요. 창업자에서 바깥으로 이어지는 다음 동심원(concentric circle)에 속한 경영진은 에너지 강도가 한 차원, 심지어는 한 자릿수(즉 십배) 수준으로 떨어질 수 있어요. 그건 진짜 위험해요.
text_zh: 创始人CEO是公司里最纯粹的野心和最强的驱动力。离创始人CEO越远的那些管理层，他们的干劲可能会断崖式下跌。这他妈的太危险了。
text_es: La forma más pura de ambición y la fuente de energía más intensa en el negocio es el CEO fundador. Cada siguiente círculo concéntrico de gerencia más allá del CEO fundador tiene el potencial de ser una caída de intensidad de un orden de magnitud. Eso es jodidamente peligroso.

text: You don't really learn from your mistakes, you learn from your successes. Of course, you learn a bit from mistakes, but I do think that this is sort of feel good that it's like, 'Well, you didn't succeed, but at least you learned something.' I've learned so much more because I've seen success.
speaker: Matt MacInnis
context: Matt challenges the common Silicon Valley wisdom that failure is the best teacher. He argues that while people do learn from mistakes, they actually learn much more from experiencing success. He contrasts his nine years at his previous company Inkling (which struggled) with his time at the successful company Rippling, noting that observing what works right provides more valuable insights than seeing what goes wrong.
text_ko: 사실 실수에서 진짜 배우는 경우보다 성공에서 더 많이 배우는 편이에요. 물론 실수로부터 어느 정도는 배우지만, '성공하진 못했지만 적어도 뭔가 배웠으니 다행' 같은 위로의 느낌도 있는 것 같아요. 저는 성공을 직접 경험하면서 훨씬 더 많은 걸 배웠어요.
text_zh: 其实你真正学到东西不是从失败中，而是从成功中。当然，失败也能学到一点，但我觉得那种"虽然没成功，但至少学到了什么"的说法更多是自我安慰。我从成功的经历中学到的东西要多得多。
text_es: En realidad no aprendes tanto de tus errores, sino de tus éxitos. Claro, algo sí aprendes de los errores, pero creo que esto de "bueno, no te fue bien, pero al menos aprendiste algo" es como para consolarse. Yo he aprendido muchísimo más porque he visto el éxito de cerca.

text: We talk in Silicon Valley about never quit, but that is complete absolute venture capital bullshit. The incentive of venture capitalist is to put money into your company and milk you dry. They never get their money back. There is no way for them to take that investment back.
speaker: Matt MacInnis
context: Matt challenges the popular Silicon Valley mentality of 'never quit' when discussing product-market fit and knowing when to shut down a startup. He argues this advice serves venture capitalists' interests rather than entrepreneurs' interests, since VCs can't get their money back once invested and benefit from founders continuing to try even when success is unlikely. This creates misaligned incentives between VCs and founders.
text_ko: 실리콘밸리(Silicon Valley)에서는 '절대 포기하지 마라'고들 말하죠. 그런데 그건 벤처 투자자(venture capitalist)들의 완전한 헛소리예요. 벤처 투자자들의 인센티브(incentive)는 당신 회사에 돈을 넣고 다 쥐어짜서 빨아먹는 거예요. 그들은 절대 투자금을 돌려받지 못해요. 투자금을 회수할 방법이 전혀 없거든요.
text_zh: 我们在硅谷总说永不放弃，但这完全就是风投(venture capital)的扯淡。风投(venture capitalist)的动机就是往你公司砸钱，然后把你榨干。他们的钱根本收不回来，也没办法把投资撤回去。
text_es: En Silicon Valley siempre hablan de "nunca te rindas", pero eso es una completa mentira de los capitalistas de riesgo. El incentivo de los venture capitalists es meter plata en tu empresa y exprimirte hasta el último centavo. Nunca recuperan su dinero. No tienen manera de retirar esa inversión.
